title: Which driver will win the 2021 Formula One World Drivers' Championship?
preds: Lewis won the third practice. Now it's time to observe the qualifying race. But I'm putting some doubt that this streak will continue. Regression to mean?
It looks like Merc are banking on their medium tire pace after the Bulls pit. https://press.pirelli.com/2021-abu-dhabi-grand-prix---saturday/ A clean race without the stewards hopefully.

Final update after quali: with Max on pole in Abu Dhabi, I'm dropping my probability for Lewis to take the race and championship down to 51%. The only reason I give Lewis that slight edge is that Max and Checo are both starting on soft tires, which theoretically means that they will have a shorter first stint than the Mercedes. Christian Horner claims that RB is reserving the option for a two-stopper, but it's hard to see that as a good strategy unless safety cars come into play.

I have no idea what happened to the pace of the Mercedes in Q3 but that's huge result for Max in quali. Starting on the softs might be slightly suboptimal, but the Red Bull's race pace looked solid yesterday and with Bottas down in 6th Red Bull might be able to have two cars to use strategically vs Hamilton.

Based on the fact that Mercedes has won the most points so far per win and Lewis has the most points per win. Based on first two practice races, Max and Lewis both won one, but the one with the greatest relative lead time was Lewis. On the other hand, Max is the strong favorite among other Formula 1 racers. On the flipside of that, the markets have Lewis as the favorite. I tried seeing patterns in race track characteristics and whether Lewis or Max takes the win but I did not find any strong correlation worth remarking, other than that this is an area others may want to take a look at. They may also want to see historical performances of Mercedes and/or the respective drivers on the Abu Dhabi track.

Pulling back slightly from 65% based on Friday practice data. Hamilton dominated FP2 on low fuel, but RB was slightly faster on race pace. https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.5-things-we-learned-from-friday-practice-at-the-abu-dhabi-grand-prix.2J6kQ6p9tbvl4TIzmjU45o.html One last update opportunity after quali!

Although it is level on points, Mr. Hamilton is my strong favourite. I actually think his chances are higher in a 'fair' race. However, with the tiebreaker meaning two DNF's give the title to Mr. Verstappen, I cannot rule out an 'accident'
Hamilton has the experience and the momentum right now. Verstappen's judgment appears to be compromised.

Hamilton win and tied after Saudi Arabian Grand Prix.  Verstappen won at Abu Dhabi last year - this year's final race.  Head lines I've seen focus on Hamilton's complaints and penalties.  Verstappen is not without penalties, but I don't see this final race as a 50-50.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WyF8RHM1OCg It looks like Mad Max is out of head space.

As much as it pains me to make this forecast, this seems to be where the evidence is pointing. Race pace is king. There are just too many long passing zones at Yas Marina, so I really don’t think it matters too much who will be on pole position (as long as VER/HAM are both ~top 4 as expected). The Merc (especially Lewis’) will stay in touch and pass with its inherent straight line speed advantage, even if RBR take an early lead, and DRS makes this a near-certainty. Max really got close, gave us a very exciting championship, but the poor guy is just very clearly out-gunned no fault of his own. I’ll leave a 3% chance for an unbelievable screw-up in the Merc garage or pit wall, but those folks don’t make a lot of mistakes when they’ve got this much of an upper hand. It’s truly been one of the greatest F1 comebacks of all time for Merc/HAM to have come back into contention with a race to spare after where they were in Mexico! Credit where credit is due.
Hamilton and Verstappen are currently tied.  Whoever beats the other in the next race wins.
My old odds were probably too favorable to Hamilton, but got lucky in a crazy Saudi Grand Prix. Modestly increasing odds

Before this weekend I thought Hamilton had around a 60% chance of winning in Abu Dhabi on current form. I'm now reducing that to 55% on the basis of Red Bull's quali pace. Will probably massively adjust predictions based on how free-practice and qualifying play out next week.

I think you're all over reacting to the error, rather than the result of qualifying. Assuming Verstappen doesn't need a new gearbox, he's still got a decent chance of winning from third on the grid given it seems Red Bull are better able to work their tyres at this track. Even with a grid drop he only needs fourth tomorrow to make sure that a win in Abu Dhabi would win him the title. It still looks overwhelmingly like it will be a straight shoot out in Abu Dhabi, and the competitive picture is so tight it's not obvious who will be faster there.

2 x 44 = 88 I clearly hadn’t factored in the close proximity of the barriers in Jeddah when crafting my previous forecasts. You don’t give Lewis this kind of gift and walk away winning the Championship. Max looked amazing. Right up to that last corner. Max’s RBR seems very unlikely to be as fast tomorrow over the race distance (some small detail will be different and noticeably unhelpful), even if they can somehow fix the car without breaking parc ferme. If not, P2 still seems possible but will be the maximum for tomorrow. Unless we see even more human factors at play shortly…12% chance.

In Saudi quali, Max just made the mistake that could decide the championship. Will increase my odds for Lewis if Max ends up replacing his gear-box and taking a five-grid-spot penalty. (The human factor is very much in play, @m_collier!)

Lewis has the momentum, he has experience of winning before, red bull focusing on the wrong stuff, red bull attitude seems weak, either of the cars could probably win on their day, but the difference is the driver.

The worm is turning. Is the Mercedes engine strategy working? What of the competitors? Teams and drivers? I'm viewing this as a closed set for many reasons.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_set The a priori view would be a front row qualy lock out for Mercedes. I don't expect Hamilton to make any more bad starts.

Current scores:  Verstappen: 351.5; Lewis 343.5, Perez 190 (4th Place).  Bottas is in 3rd at 203 points.  Verstappen could claim the championship as early as 5 Dec with a win in Jeddah; however, Lewis could still take the trophy.

If the trend continues favoring Lewis, Max may lose by just a few points in the next 2 races? However, I don't think Lewis will win the last race and the next 2 in a row. So I say the odds are stacked against him.

Revising my forecast to make this a dead-heat based on learning that Hamilton was using an old engine in Qatar, not the one that had such dominating performance at Interlagos. https://www.essentiallysports.com/f1-news-revealed-mercedes-f1-directors-reason-for-using-lewis-hamiltons-old-engine-in-qatar/ Max still has the benefit of the 8-point lead, as well as the tie-breaker (https://www.racefans.net/2021/11/22/how-verstappen-can-win-the-formula-1-championship-at-the-next-race/), which is why I give him even odds of winning the championship despite the performance advantage for Mercedes. I also see Checo as being a more reliable co-driver than Bottas.

Toning down my prediction slightly on the basis of thinking a bit more about the probabilities. If you exclude unusual events such as unreliability, tyre failures, slow pit  stops etc then you'd expect Hamilton and Verstappen to finish 1st and 2nd in the final two rounds. Hamilton would need to win both and Verstappen only needs to win one of them. So even though I'm assuming Hamilton is a very strong favourite for Saudi Arabia, and a solid favourite for Abu Dhabi if you assign those probabilities of 0.85 and 0.6 then he's still only at ~50% to win the title.

Some look at Hamilton's last two racing weekends and see momentum. I look at Verstappen's recoveries and see strength and determination. He came back strong from a 5-grid-spot penalty (not for the "right to review" of the Brazil incident, but from a failure to observe double-yellow flags during quali), to minimize the damage with both a 2nd-place finish and an extra point for the fastest lap. The latter was especially impressive as it suggests that the current Mercedes pace advantage over Red Bull is not as definitive as it seemed in Brazil and in Qatar quali. I took the risk of a day's bad scores to ponder this forecast overnight. In the end, I did raise my odds for a Hamilton championship from 20% to 35%, but I am staying below the current crowd consensus. Eight points and two races to go is certainly within Hamilton's capabilities, but I'm sure he'd still rather be in Verstappen's shoes. A plea to my fellow forecasters: PLEASE post rationales with your forecasts; it's hard to evaluate why the crowd has become so much more optimistic about Hamilton's chances. Yes, he's had two great races and is a proven winner. (Heads up, BTW: he has an upcoming MasterClass on a "winning mindset"!) But there are so many ways for things to go wrong, and Verstappen does have the luxury of that eight-point cushion.

Today's HAM-VER battle went about as expected in Qatar. No surprising developments (that I could see) that would change the outlook for the final two races, compared to what we already knew after Brazil. Fortunate for VER to be able to take fastest lap / do damage limitation.
Running probabilistic analysis of all the previous race outcomes in this season (described at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1342535 ) now suggests VER chances of winning are 68%, if base rates are predictive. I'm continuing to deviate significantly from base rates in my forecast because of the apparent (and recently developed) superiority of the Mercedes car in the high-speed, low altitude tracks that are coming up. VER and HAM will both make the most (or perhaps even slightly more than can be expected!) from the package they are given to race. Championship seems like a complete coin toss now, where whoever blinks first loses.

Mercedes look ominously fast and the gap is coming down. I think Hamilton is now marginal favourite and unless something odd happens it's going to come down to a simple case of who wins in Abu Dhabi. Cracking season.

Brazil was an absolutely crucial race for Mercedes, and it went about as well for them as they could've possibly hoped (or even better?!).  Can HAM/Mercedes Team perfectly execute another 3 races in a row in this kind of dominant fashion? That's probably what it'll take to be assured of a Championship win, given the remaining VER points lead, and continued RBR high-performance when there are corners. I'm therefore still leaning slightly towards VER becoming champion.  But wow, have the probability margins narrowed again just because of this race! Looking back at my previous forecasts, I don't think my probabilities were out of line with what was seen at the time. It just seems that one of the much less likely outcomes in my scenario range has now expressed: a late, very significant change in relative performance in the Mercedes cars vs RBR that matters over a race distance. Although my running probabilistic analysis of historical outcomes this season (described at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1342535) still suggests that VER chances of winning the championship are ~77% post-Brazil, I think it's quite appropriate/necessary to make a forecast that significantly deviates away from such full-season base rate reference points. The new evidence from today's full-length race--although quite surprising to me--is impressive and compelling.  It appears that in the final races of this amazing season, we'll see how tough VER and the RBR team really are. It is always foolish to count HAM out completely, but the same should be said for VER as well! It's not a given that the technological performance edge that Mercedes have apparently now created for themselves can be converted into the wins necessary, if the team drops the ball on strategy, pit work, or driver errors under pressure (that last one's admittedly a very tiny chance, but the first two should be of real concern to Mercedes, in my opinion, based on their increased frequency of questionable strategy calls and errors vs in the past when they were not really under threat by any other teams). Clearly, whoever wins will take one of the most deserved Championship wins in a long time!

Feel slightly vindicated by my caution yesterday. The pace advantage of the Merc is a real problem for Verstappen now and his lead is very precarious. If Hamilton wins the next two races then he'll lead the championship, which seems probable on current form. We'll have to see if there's any further investigations into Merc's rear wing or if the engine degrades in performance going into the final rounds. But the title race is now extremely finely poised.

For months I've been more bullish on Verstappen's chances than the crowd, but I'm slightly surprised by the way the crowd has reacted this weekend. After today I'm tweaking my prediction to slightly increase Hamilton's chances. My prediction has largely been between 65%-70% for Verstappen since I started predicting this question, but the reasoning has evolved because the relative perfomance of the cars has changed.  I had previously thought the Red Bull would be prove to be marginally stronger and that would tell over a long series of races. But now I think Mercedes probably now has a slight edge on the remaining tracks. And my confidence in Verstappen getting over the line is largely a function of the points lead vs points remaining rather than car performance.  A Mercedes 1-2 in Saudi Arabia and a Hamilton- Verstappen 1-2 in Qatar and Abu Dhabi would likely still hand Hamilton the title. And such a scenario seems decently plausable on current form.

RBR performance (completely objectively, Mercedes just received a SPANKING in Mexico) should be expected to continue into Brazil, with a few extra points available to VER (or HAM) for the sprint. Updated probabilistic calculation (as first described at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1342535) suggests that VER chances of winning the championship are now ~84%. With 4 races to run, and with VER holding the high ground in points and in momentum, most paths for HAM to come back into the lead now involve unexpected mechanical problems or a very unlikely gross error by RBR/VER during upcoming races. HAM pretty much needs to win almost all races from here on out for his championship hopes to remain credible. Correspondingly, the 15% victory chances now assessed for HAM track closely with my forecast for the likelihood of a major mechanical or driver error hurting VER over the next 4 races. Probably also noteworthy that only in the very first 4 races of this season have we ever seen HAM beat VER over a consecutive 4-race series within the Championship. Evaluation of all other possible 4-race segments (e.g., Race #5 - Race #8) throughout this season involves a pretty even win tally or a VER advantage (if there are no major unexpected racing incidents, etc.). So, if the recent past is at all predictive of future outcomes, it's looking VERY good for VER now.

Still uncertain at the time of this post whether Hamilton will take another engine, with the associated grid penalty, for this weekend's Mexico City Grand Prix. But if he doesn't, he will be exposed to greater risk of a DNF for engine failure in this high-altitude race. Either way, this is a tough race for Mercedes on a track that has favored Red Bull in recent history. Combining these factors with the FP2 results (Verstappen in the lead, Hamilton third, with Perez a close fourth) and the "home race" motivation for Perez, I see Verstappen adding to his lead over Hamilton this weekend − with at least a 30% chance that Hamilton will fail to make the podium. That would leave Hamilton with a very difficult path to the championship. Of the four remaining tracks after Mexico City, only the new Saudi Arabia street circuit is viewed as favoring Mercedes. https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.tech-tuesday-with-five-races-to-go-in-2021-which-circuits-will-suit-red-bull.9Qa1ZLFQlB5XbYXUWny7P.html I'll need to update this forecast based on Sunday's results. Key factors:
● Final point spread between Verstappan and Hamilton in Mexico City (if Max wins and Lewis finishes off the podium, I'll increase my forecast for Verstappen);
● Any DNFs (both drivers DNF = no change; only one driver DNFs, a forecast swing in the other driver's favor).

Como era de esperar esta temporada 2021 de la Formula 1 se iban a llevar todo el protagonismo tan solo dos pilotos, Lewis Hamilton de la escudería Mercedes y Max Verstappen de la escudería Red Bull Racing. Con los resultados de las primeras 13 fechas siguen peleando mano a mano sin casi darse ventajas, se encuentran con tan solo 3 puntos de ventaja (Verstappen sobre Hamilton) y a 101.5 puntos del tercer lugar lo cual es muchísimo. Quedando 9 fechas la pregunta del momento es quien va a ser campeón y por qué.
Para realizar un análisis un poco mas critico se analizara el auto de cada piloto lo cual es fundamental a la hora de hablar de un campeonato y capacidad sobre el volante en esta temporada. En primer lugar, es difícil comparar los autos ya que ambos anduvieron muy bien en las pruebas pre-temporada pero fue el mismo jefe del equipo mercedes James Vowles quien dijo que tenían una desventaja frente a Red Bull, ya que los neumáticos de estos ultimo se calentaban mucho mas rápido por lo que sacaban ventaja en las primeras vueltas. Posterior a esto salió Red Bull a contrarrestar la ventaja ya que según ellos esto les juega en contra al final de la carrera. Así mismo se pueden pasar toda la temporada un equipo peleando con el otro por lo tanto la comparación la voy a hacer con los segundos pilotos de cada equipo para ver como les ha ido, mirando los resultados de Sergio Pérez (Red Bull) y Valteri Bottas (Mercedes) se ve que tampoco son mucho las diferencias, Bottas va en tercer lugar y Pérez en quinto lugar lo que demuestra que los autos son muy parecidos, además considerando que Pérez a cometido un par de errores en la pista. Dicho esto, podemos decir que con respecto a los autos no hay diferencias notorias.
En segundo lugar, el manejo de los pilotos es complicado de criticar ya que se ven muy influenciados por el jefe del equipo y la estrategia que se les plantea, muchas veces cometen errores pero es debido a que están siendo presionados desde los boxes. Para comparar esto utilizaremos la única carrera del año con lluvia ya que es en ese minuto donde la sensibilidad del piloto se expresa al máximo, es mas, dicen que es aquí donde se va la diferencia entre pilotos y maestros. En el circuito de Spa-Francorchamps la lluvia fue torrencial y pese a que no se pudo terminar la carrera, de hecho se corrieron pocas vueltas, quedo Verstappen primero y Hamilton tercero, además es importante considerar que Verstappen viene conduciendo muy bien en lluvia hace un par de años.
Para terminar, sin lugar a dudad va a ser una pelea muy reñida de aquí a final de temporada entre estos dos pilotos pero por un mejor manejo de Verstappen, en mi opinión, puede sacar ventajas este año y ser campeón.

F1 has completed 10 races of its expected 23 race schedule. Hamilton and Verstappen are neck and neck, separated by only 8 points, while Perez is 72 points behind. To give a sense of scale, Perez needs to win 3 races (75 points) while Hamilton and Verstappen both DNF (do not finish) to take the lead. That is almost certainly not going to happen, so I think it's clear it's either Verstappen or Hamilton. Right now, I give a slight edge to Verstappen - he's won more races, has a slight lead, and his car has looked better in recent weeks.
I looked at a few recent Championships and the eventual winners seem to dominate throughout the season. Not surprising since points are cumulative

This is a two-man race. There is no way that Red Bull would let Perez take the championship unless Verstappen can't finish the season. And I doubt that Perez could outdrive Hamilton, who is deeply motivated to win his record-breaking eighth world championship. Despite the surprising Silverstone result, Verstappen has a clear edge. The Red Bull team seems once again to have Adrian Newey's full attention on aerodynamics, and their Honda engine has finally equalled, or even surpassed, the mighty Mercedes motor. Red Bull excels in pit stops, whereas Mercedes and Toto Wolff have been uncharacteristically weak on both tactical and strategic execution. Things to watch: Hamilton's renewed confidence and commitment after his strong British Grand Prix outcome can still make a difference. Verstappen's high-speed crash may have lingering effects that will take time to manifest. Mercedes may make greater-than-expected engineering strides during the summer break. The first two factors could be apparent during the upcoming Hungarian Grand Prix; the third won't be evident until at least September. If Hamilton manages to hold his own or even pull ahead in the championship by the end of September, game on. Otherwise, I'll be steadily increasing my odds for Verstappen.

Being a moderate F1 fan, I have a bit of knowledge coming into this question.  First, I have no doubt that either Lewis Hamilton or Max Verstappen will be the champion come the end of the season.  They have won 9/10 races so far this season, and have a points lead over third that equates to more than 2 victories (meaning third place would need to win twice while Hamilton and Verstappen collect 0 points).  Even if that were to happen, third place would still be behind and would have to outperform Hamilton and Verstappen in the final third of the season.  Looking at Hamilton vs Verstappen is much more interesting, though.  Lewis Hamilton, currently in second place, is 8 points behind Verstappen.  However, Hamilton has won 6 of the last 7 World Drivers' Championships (85%), while Verstappen has never won.  With 13 races left in the season, both racers are more than capable of being on top at the end.  However, I've picked Hamilton to win for a few reasons.  First, an 8 point lead is incredibly slim (can easily be made up in one race given these racers win nearly every single race).  Second, Hamilton won 9 of the final 13 races last season, while Verstappen only won 1.  Were this to happen again, Hamilton would run away with the Championship.  Finally, Hamilton is undoubtedly the greatest F1 driver of all time, with championship experience.  All of these things give him an edge over Verstappen.  However, I did check Draftkings for betting odds, and Max Verstappen is actually the odds-on favorite to win the Championship (-190 vs Hamilton at +150).  Removing the Vig from these odds, this makes Hamilton a slight underdog.  Based on all these factors, I've decided to give Hamilton a slight edge at the moment, and will adjust based on following race results.
